intro: Commiphora hornbyi, commonly known as the hornby's myrrh, is a small evergreen shrub native to the arid regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the Burseraceae family, which includes other resin-producing plants. The plant is characterized by its dense, leathery leaves and produces a fragrant resin that has been used traditionally for its medicinal properties. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to withstand drought conditions. Due to its unique botanical features and limited distribution, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists alike.
